title: How to Determine a Square and Circle of Equal Area

steps.title: Let r1^2 represent the area of the square, A(s).
steps.content: Let r1^2 represent the area of the square, A(s).

steps.title: Let πr2^2 = the area of the circle, A(c).
steps.content: Let πr2^2 = the area of the circle, A(c).

steps.title: Set A(s) = A(c) via r1^2 = πr2^2.
steps.content: Set A(s) = A(c) via r1^2 = πr2^2.

steps.title: Then r1^2 / r2^2 = π and r1 / r2 = sqrt(π).
steps.content: Then r1^2 / r2^2 = π and r1 / r2 = sqrt(π).

steps.title: Given either r1 or r2, we can determine the other one.
steps.content: Given either r1 or r2, we can determine the other one. That is: r1 = sqrt(π)*r2 and r2 = r1/sqrt(π). sqrt(π) = 1.77245385090552. So, given a square of side r1 = 1.77245385090552, its area = 1.77245385090552^2 = π and r2 = r1/sqrt(π) or 1.77245385090552/1.77245385090552 = 1 and the area of r2's circle = πr2^2 = π(1)^2 = π, which equals the area of the square just calculated.

steps.title: And it's been learned that the square root of π means the relationship between the equal areas of a square and circle of varying "radius."
steps.content: And it's been learned that the square root of π means the relationship between the equal areas of a square and circle of varying "radius."
